text:
Opportunities we pursue are often less valuable than a few great ones.  

Once we understand this, we scan for the vital few.  

We eagerly eliminate the trivial many.  

Only then can we say no to good opportunities.  

We say yes to truly great ones.  

This is why an Essentialist explores all options.  

The extra investment is justified.  

Some things are much more important.  

They repay the effort tenfold.  

An Essentialist discerns more so he can do less.  

A Nonessentialist thinks almost everything is essential.  

He views opportunities as basically equal.  

He thinks almost everything is nonessential.  

He distinguishes the vital few from the trivial many.  

Many capable people struggle to advance.  

They can't let go of the belief that everything is important.  

An Essentialist learns to tell the difference.  

He knows what is truly important and what is not.  

To practice this skill, we start at a simple level.  

Once it becomes second nature, we apply it to bigger areas.  

These areas include our personal and professional lives.  

Mastering it fully requires a massive shift in thinking.  

But it can be done.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** An Essentialist focuses on identifying and pursuing the few truly valuable opportunities while eliminating the trivial many.
